question: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-week history of burning sensation in his mouth. One year ago, a peripheral blood smear performed during workup of fatigue revealed erythrocytes without central pallor. His father had gallstones, for which he underwent a cholecystectomy at the age of 26 years. Examination shows pallor of the mucosal membranes, mild scleral icterus, a swollen, red tongue, and several mouth ulcers. There is darkening of the skin over the dorsal surfaces of the fingers, toes, and creases of the palms and soles. His spleen is enlarged and palpable 3 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.1 gm/dL, mean corpuscular volume of 104 μm3, and a reticulocyte count of 9%. Which of the following would most likely have prevented this patient's oropharyngeal symptoms?

The patient's father had gallstones, which led to a cholecystectomy. The patient's laboratory studies show a low hemoglobin concentration, high mean corpuscular volume (MCV), and a reticulocyte count of 9%. These findings are suggestive of megaloblastic anemia, which is often caused by a deficiency in vitamin B12 or folate. The patient's symptoms of burning sensation in the mouth and mouth ulcers are consistent with glossitis, which is often seen in megaloblastic anemia. The darkening of the skin over the dorsal surfaces of the fingers, toes, and creases of the palms and soles is also consistent with megaloblastic anemia. Red blood cell transfusions: While transfusions may help alleviate the patient's anemia, they do not address the underlying cause of the megaloblastic anemia. B. Gluten-free diet: A gluten-free diet is typically recommended for patients with celiac disease, which is an autoimmune disorder that causes malabsorption of nutrients, including vitamin B12. However, there is no indication of celiac disease in the patient's history. C. Vitamin B12 injections: Vitamin B12 injections are a common treatment for megaloblastic anemia caused by a deficiency in vitamin B12. This is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms. D. Folic acid supplementation: While folic acid supplementation may be necessary to treat megaloblastic anemia, it is not the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms, as the patient's reticulocyte count is elevated, suggesting that the anemia is not solely due to folic acid deficiency. Therefore, the correct answer is: {"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient presents with symptoms of megaloblastic anemia, including glossitis and darkening of the skin, which are consistent with a deficiency in vitamin B12. The symptoms of scarlet fever are the same as those of pharyngitis alone. The rash typically begins on the first or second day of illness over the upper trunk, spreading to involve the extremities but sparing the palms and soles. The rash is made up of minute papules, giving a characteristic “sandpaper” feel to the skin. Associated findings include circumoral pallor, “strawberry tongue” (enlarged papillae on a coated tongue, which later may become denuded), and accentuation of the rash in skinfolds (Pastia’s lines). Subsidence of the rash in 6–9 days is followed after several days by desquamation of the palms and soles. The differential diagnosis of scarlet fever includes other causes of fever and generalized rash, such as measles and other viral exanthems, Kawasaki disease, TSS, and systemic allergic reactions (e.g., drug eruptions).

snippets.title: InternalMed_Harrison
snippets.content: The examination of a peripheral blood smear is one of the most informative exercises a physician can perform. Although advances in automated technology have made the examination of a peripheral blood smear by a physician seem less important, the technology is not a completely satisfactory replacement for a blood smear interpretation by a trained medical professional who also knows the patient’s clinical history, family history, social history, and physical findings. It is useful to ask the laboratory to generate a Wright’s-stained peripheral blood smear and examine it. The best place to examine blood cell morphology is the feathered edge of the blood smear where red cells lie in a single layer, side by side, just barely touching one another but not overlapping. The author’s approach is to look at the smallest cellular elements, the platelets, first and work his way up in size to red cells and then white cells.
